prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IR04454-4838
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe HCN, CS, HCO+ and continuum in IR04454-4838

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To take full advantage of the band-7 resolution and achieve sufficient SNR and uv plane coverage we will observe each galaxy for about 55 mins (including overheads and calibration). Two of our sources have published CO (1-0) fluxes, and we have used these to estimate the HCO+ (4-3) fluxes, assuming HCO+ is a factor of 0.3 times the flux in CO (1-0) (Baan et al. 2008, Wilson et al. 2008). We require 1-sigma limits of 1.5 mJy, which will give us a SNR > 10 in the HCO+ feature. Based on other LIRGs observed with PdBI and ALMA, the HCN (4-3) line typically has a peak flux desnity of 0.5% of the 60-micron flux density - suggesting a peak HCN line at about 50 mJy. This will be easily detected. If the vibrationally excited HCN transition has about 1/5 - 1/3 of this flux (Aalto et al. 2015) then we will achieve SNR = 5-10.
Note the CS line in IR04454-4838 lies in a low transmission atmospheric window, so here we may not achieve high SNR in CS. Since we are observing multiple high density tracers (CS, HCN and HCO+), we will rely on the HCN and HCO+ maps for this source to measure the gas in and around the nucleus.
We will bin all spectra to 10 km/s resolution - sufficient to analyze the line profiles and search for double peaks and line wings, but coarse enough to provide excellent SNR. Based on observations of other LIRGs in the local Universe, we expect the lines to have widths of 200-500 km/s, and possibly double peaks and broad wings.
From published measurements (Wilson et al. 2008) we estimate that the 872 micron continuum flux density to be approximately 1% of the 60 micron flux density, or about 70 mJy, ensuring a high SNR ratio map even if a significant fraction of the dust is resolved. The continuum measurement will be binned across the entire channel for maximum SNR.

We will observe all four galaxies in band-7 in extended array configuration. The spectral windows are centered on the HCN (4-3) 354.4 GHz, HCO+ (4-3) 356.7 GHz, and CS (7-6) 342.9 GHz transitions, with one window designated for the dust continuum at ~872 microns (~344 GHz). The HCO+ window will include the z=1 excited transition of HCN. The spectral windows for the emission lines have bandwidths of 1875 MHz to ensure adequate coverage of broad, or multiple-peaked features. These lines can have wide FWHM (few hundred or more km/s) and fainter wings so the wide bands are necessary. We have averaged by 8x to achieve a lower data rate, and we will bin to a spectral resolution of 10 km/s, which is sufficient to resolve the lines and achieve high SNR. The bandwidth for the continuum dust channel is chosen to be slightly narrower (937.5 MHz) to fit in the window with the wide CS band, and since high spectral resolution is not required for the continuum.

We have used the existing HST ACS/WFC WFC3 and NICMOS images to simulate (via the CASA ALMA tool) the distribution of molecular gas on sub-kpc scales. While the HST data are dominated by starlight and hot dust, the provide our highest resolution proxy for the underlying distribution of molecular gas. While the galaxies are large, the bright central regions that we want to map with ALMA are smaller than the primary beam (< 10 arcsec across). The largest angular scale we need to resolve is set at 2 arcsec, comparable to or larger than the largest individual structures seen in the HST data (see Fig.3). The angular resolution is chosen to match existing HST visual and NIR imaging data (0.1 arcsec FWHM) allowing us to directly link the gas and stars on scales of 30-100pc. Existing ALMA imaging of other LIRGs suggests the central structures (disks, intranuclear gas) has features on these scales, so it is important to resolve these structures with ALMA to map the structure and model the dynamics of the gas.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With the IRS on the Spitzer Space Telescope we have been able to probe the energy sources, the dust and the warm molecular gas (H2) content on kpc scales in large numbers of low-redshift Luminous Infrared Galaxies (LIRGs). In a small fraction of LIRGs, there is so much obscuration (A_V > 50-100 mag) that even the mid-infrared gives us only the barest hint of the physical conditions in the circum-nuclear ISM that powers star-formation and fuels a central active nucleus. These highly shrouded galaxies are rare, yet very interesting because they may represent a brief transition phase in the evolution of a gas-rich merger to an optically visible QSO. Here we request 3.99 hrs to observe four of the most highly obscured, nearby LIRGs with ALMA in Band 7 to obtain maps of the circum-nuclear molecular gas in the HCN 4-3, HCO+ and CS 7-6 lines along with 872 micron dust continuum on 50pc scales. These data will provide the first high spatial resolution look at the mophology and dynamics of the dense molecular gas and dust in these galaxies, establishing an important baseline for future observations of dusty, merging galaxies at high-redshift.
